title: Tracey Cox reveals the love and relationship truths that we refuse to accept
text:
These are the five home truths that your friends and parents will never tell you.

They apply whether you’re in your first relationship as a teenager or your twentieth as an adult.

They will manifest in new relationships, decades-long relationships, regardless of your sexual orientation or age.

If you want keep your relationships happy and your sanity in check, these are the five truths you need to accept.

That no matter how much your partner loves you…

They’ll watch porn even if they’re having great sex with you

Most people post-40 have come to terms with the fact that their partner watches porn when they aren’t around, at least now and then.

So long as it’s not being used as a replacement for real life sex or becoming an obsession, it’s generally seen as harmless.

Lots of couples watch it together.

British sex and dating expert Tracey Cox, reveals the five home truths to keep in check for a happy relationship - including accepting that your partner watches porn (file image)

Tell an 18-year-old girl that her boyfriend will continue to watch porn – even when he’s having lots of great sex with her – and she will react with bewilderment and anger.

The concept that we should be ‘enough’ for our partners and answer every sexual need they have is highly appealing – but unworkable.

What happens if you fancy sex and your partner isn’t there? Three minutes of masturbating to porn solves that problem in an instant.

What if you’re craving the excitement of sex with someone you haven’t already slept with? Watching a stranger onscreen have sex with someone you’d quite like to, is the next best thing.

Watching porn doesn’t mean you aren’t being sexually satisfied by your partner, don’t find them attractive or wish they looked and acted like the person you’re looking at onscreen.

It’s simply a sensible way to satisfy natural sexual urges that might otherwise make you vulnerable to cheating or having an affair.

They’ll keep on masturbating

I am constantly astonished when I meet or hear from people who consider masturbating ‘cheating’ – even without porn thrown in.

Yet there’s a percentage of the population who do believe that if their partner satisfies themselves solo, it means something is horribly wrong.

If your partner isn’t having sex with you at all or rarely - and only has sex solo – it is indeed a problem.

Sex expert Tracey Cox (pictured) shares her advice for a successful love life

But if you’re having happy, regular sex and find out they’re supplementing that now and then with solo sex, there is nothing to worry about.

Solo sex is all about scratching a different kind of itch.

Most of us can DIY in under five minutes.

Sex with your partner requires several things.

First, that your partner is around and also wants to have sex. If they’re not there or don’t want to have sex, masturbating is one way of relieving sexual tension, so you don’t turn into a sex pest.

Partner sex takes time and effort. You have to arouse your partner and (usually) make sure they orgasm as well.

Sometimes, you don’t have time for all that or you feel like a snack not the full three courses.

Or you want selfish sex.

Masturbating means you have no-one to worry about but yourself: it’s a simple pleasure release that’s blissfully without judgement.

They’ll still find other people attractive

Even if you think your partner is the most attractive/sexy/beautiful/handsome person you have ever met in the world, ever, it still won’t stop you noticing that other people are also pleasing to the eye.

Love and commitment stop us acting on this attraction – they don’t stop us experiencing it.

Being with someone who openly checks out other people in front of you is totally unacceptable, of course.

But seeing your partner’s eyes do an involuntary flicker when someone hot comes into view isn’t something worth getting het up about.

Tracey says love doesn't stop us from experiencing attraction to others, it's not worth getting upset over your partner's eyes involuntarily looking at someone hot (file image)

If it really bothers you, do what I do: acknowledge the other person’s beauty so they have permission to look.

“Check out that girl’s legs,” I’ll say to my husband. Or ‘God, how good looking is she!”.

I’d rather direct his gaze than see him sneak a look.

More challenging is when your partner has a friend who is good-looking or annoyingly charismatic.

But, while it might be blindingly obvious to you that his best female friend makes most men’s heads swivel, he might not even notice anymore.

Or she’s not his type. Or he prefers her as a friend.

Just because we think someone is attractive, doesn’t mean we act on it or even want to.

Admiring beauty is one of life’s pleasures.

Whether it be looking at a painting, flower, a baby or grown person, staring at beautiful things is just what humans do.

They’ll fantasise about other people

Just about everyone has sexual fantasies: 90 per cent of women and 96 per cent of men have them daily.

They’re a portable, potent sex aid with lots of benefits –that also cause a great deal of distress.

Imagining something in your head is an entirely different matter than doing it in real life but lots of people consider them a betrayal.

Sometimes, people do have sex with other people or leave their partners for people they’ve been fantasising about.

Tracey says that almost everyone has sexual fantasies about other people, however pressuring your partner to talk about their's just causes paranoia (file image)

But most don’t.

For most people, fantasies are more pleasant, erotic daydreams than unexpressed desire. We’ll conjure up sexual situations we have no desire at all to fulfil in real life.

They’re a way of solving the main problem people have with monogamy: sexual boredom. A means of satisfying a craving for sexual variety, safely, without hurting our partner.

Most people adopt the ‘don’t ask, don’t tell’ policy with fantasies because most of us don’t want to know that someone we love is having lustful thoughts about someone else.

Forcing your partner to admit they sometimes fantasise about other people accomplishes absolutely nothing but make them feel guilty and you paranoid.

They’ll hate you as well as love you

Even if you were to accomplish what is unachievable - do every single thing right and never upset your partner - they would still have days where they feel resentful of you.

Or are bored by you. Annoyed by you. And yes, hate you as well.

Arguing is healthy: it means you’re not afraid to speak up about things that upset you. Anger is healthy, too: it means you care deeply about each other.

Love isn’t a straight line. Even the best relationships have ups and downs.

It’s indifference, not flashes of hatred, that kills relationships.

description: Sex and relationship expert Tracey Cox, reveals the five home truths that you should accept for a happy relationship - including the fact your partner will watch porn despite a good sex life.
